channel.title: APM: The Story
channel.description: The Story with Dick Gordon brings the news home - through passionate points of view and personal experiences. The program brings together ordinary and extraordinary people to provide perspective on the issues which affect us all. Our goal is to inspire conversation, thinking and understanding. Produced at North Carolina Public Radio - WUNC.
channel.itunes:author: American Public Media

item.title: This One Goes Out To Kate (6.27.2013)
item.description: Charlene Strong became an activist for equality after she was denied entrance into the hospital of her dying partner Kate. Also in this show: whether tacky legal ads bring down the profession or make it more accessible; and the brave lawyers who make jokes in the toughest room of all: the U.S. Supreme Court.

item.title: A Fresh Start (6.26.2013)
item.description: Dr. David Ores, a physician known for giving free tattoo removal, says there’s a great need for his services in New York City. Also in this show: a look at the emerging renaissance of sign painters; and personal trainer Bryant Johnson builds the bodies of the law: Justices Ruth Bader Ginsburg and Elena Kagan.

item.title: Eight Years Old With An AK-47
item.description: An eight-year-old on the front lines of the Syrian civil war, caught on film. Also in this show: Architect Raphael Sperry asks fellow architects to refuse to design prisons for prolonged solitary confinement, which he says are for “cruel, inhuman, or degrading treatment;" and it took Debra Britt, a lifelong collector of dolls, more than 50 years to find one that looked like her.

item.title: Peeping The Cloud: A Journey To The Center Of Cloud Computing (6.24.2013)
item.description: Guest host Sean Cole joins Benjamen Walker of the Theory of Everything podcast to dissect cloud computing: how it works, what we gain from it, and the Chinese mines that produce the rare elements that powers it.

item.title: For Congress Freshman, First Six Months Teach Patience (6.21.2013)
item.description: Six months into his freshman term in congress, Markwayne Mullin talks about refocusing from short-term gains to long-term goals. Also in this show: Carlos Martinez, an immigrant who got a work permit for the first time last year, has finally been able to find a job using his computer engineering degree; Sara Isaacson, an ROTC Cadet dismissed from service because she came out as lesbian, talks about how the repeal of “Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell” allowed her to return to service; two months before his “I Have a Dream” speech in Washington, Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. led the Great March to Freedom in Detroit; and in 1896, Williams Jennings Bryan gave one of the greatest speeches in American politics.

item.title: Shut Off Your Engines Please: One Man’s Mission (6.20.2013)
item.description: Host Dick Gordon speaks with New Yorker George Pakenham, who asks idling drivers to shut off their engines. Also in this show: Garret Ean likes to drop quarters in expired parking meters – not just out of kindness, but to prevent the city from making money on parking tickets; and long-time Detroit arts patron Harriet Berg talks about meeting Mexican muralist Diego Rivera and her city’s underground art lovers.

item.title: Affirmative Action: Fall Down, Get Back Up Again (6.19.2013)
item.description: An African American student’s struggle to succeed at the University of Texas. Also in this show: high-wire walker Nik Wallenda on his planned walk across the Grand Canyon; and two little girls explain the “worst haircut ever.”

item.title: The Voting Rights Act Of 1964 (06.18.13)
item.description: As the U.S. Supreme Court considers the Voting Rights Act of 1965, host Dick Gordon speaks with an activist and a resident who were at the center of the civil rights fight in Holmes County, Miss.

item.title: South Boston And Whitey Bulger (6.17.2013)
item.description: Guest host Phoebe Judge speaks with Michael Patrick McDonald, who is covering the Whitey Bulger trial. He grew up in South Boston, where Bulger is a legend. Also in this show: Haley Morris-Cafiero, an overweight photographer, has been taking photos of people who mock her body; and Kristen Ulmer, who became one of the best skiers in the world by taking jumps without fear.

item.title: The Opera Couple (6.14.2013)
item.description: Ailyn Perez and Stephen Costello are husband-and-wife opera singers. They talk with Dick about the peculiarity of their relationship, which includes competing to see who can hold the longest notes, and trying to get cast in the same productions so that they can spend time together. Also in this show, wildlife photographer Tim Laman tells Dick about his journey to photograph every species of the Birds of Paradise. It took him 8 years and 18 expeditions to do it, and there are still a few he was not able to capture. The feathers and colors are hard to believe.

item.title: After Innocence: Exoneration in America, Day 4
item.description: Jennifer Thompson was a college student when she was raped. During the attack Jennifer tried to memorize what the man looked like so she could identify him later. Jennifer identified Ronald Cotton. Cotton served 11 years before he was exonerated. Also, Lamonte Armstrong was sentenced to life in prison for the murder of his elderly next door neighbor. He was exonerated last summer and is still trying to negotiate life in a world he was removed from for years.

item.title: After Innocence: Exoneration In America, Day 3
item.description: Jason Puracal was working in Nicaragua when he was wrongfully convicted of drug trafficking, money laundering, and organized crime.  He was sentenced to 22 years in one of the worst prisons in the country.  His sister Janis led the charge for his release. Also, a forensic DNA expert who has devoted himself to using new DNA technology to free the innocent.

item.title: After Innocence: Exoneration in America, Day 2
item.description: After Innocence: Exoneration in America. Day 2. Guests includeScott Hornoff, a Rhode Island police officer convicted of murder in 1996. Since his exoneration he has been unable to find work in this country so he has become a private security consultant in Afghanistan. Also: Julie Baumer, convicted of child abuse for what later was determined to be “shaken baby syndrome”. She was exonerated. And the man at the Innocence Project who receives thousands of letters from prisoners hoping to be freed.

item.title: After Innocence: Exoneration in America, Day 1
item.description: Guests include Gloria Killian, released after discovery of evidence suppression. Ray Towler, exonerated by DNA evidence. Brian Banks, exonerated and signed with football’s Atlanta Falcons. John Thompson, freed after prosecutor’s deathbed admission of suppression of evidence.

item.title: Americans Spying On Americans (6.7.2013)
item.description:
William Binney has worked in intelligence since the Cold War. As a cryptomathemetician, he helped create a new surveillance system called Thin Thread. When he discovered that Thin Thread was being used to spy on American citizens, he spoke up and eventually left the agency. 

< span>Also in this show, listeners respond to our show about preventive mastectomies, and a veteran of D-Day remembers hiding a sketchbook in his gas mask and drawing while his fellow soldiers slept.

item.title: Fighting For Workers' Rights in Bangladesh (6.6.2013)
item.description: In late April, more than 1,100 garment workers were killed in Bangladesh when the eight-story Rana Plaza building collapsed. Labor activist Kalpona Akter has come from Bangladesh to attend tomorrow's Walmart shareholders meeting in Bentonville, Arkansas, where she will try to convince shareholders that Walmart must protect the safety of factory workers. Also in this show, an audio portrait of a Washington, D.C. bus driver, and a cardiologist who closes his office and enrolls in Divinity School.

item.title: Employment: Security Hacker (6.05.2013)
item.description:
Jim Stickley is a professional hacker. Companies hire him to attempt to hack into their financial information, and identify weaknesses in their security practices.  

Also in this show, Cici McNair, a Paris-based private investigator who got her start hiding in bushes, and a man who is obsessively searching for every single Tim Wallach baseball card.

item.title: The Preventive Mastectomy: Two Women, Two Choices (6.4.2013)
item.description: When actress Angelina Jolie told the world she’d elected to have a preventative double mastectomy, people paid attention.  For Nell Boeschenstein, the news story felt personal. Nell also carries the BRCA-1 gene. After her aunt and sister developed breast cancer, Nell had a preventative double mastectomy at 31 years old. Also in this show, Dr. Daniela Drake, who was diagnosed with LCIS, was surprised when her doctor recommended a preventative mastectomy. She decided not to have the procedure.

item.title: This Land Is My Land (6.3.2013)
item.description:
Except when it isn't.

We check back in with Julia Trigg Crawford who is fighting the TransCanada Corporation as it lays pipe for the XL Pipeline. The digging has begun – in spite of ongoing litigation. 

Also in this show, Sandra Steingraber was arrested on Earth Day, and spent 15 days in jail, for protesting against hydraulic fracturing (fracking).  After many years in laboratories, and speaking at panels, she felt the time had come to use her body in direct-action protest.

item.title: When I Was Kidnapped (5.31.2013)
item.description: Rose Maura Lorre was kidnapped in 1982 in New Jersey. She was seven years old. While many kidnapping survivors aren 't able to tell their stories, Rose says she told her story a lot. Too much, she says. Also in this show, an audio portrait from Moore, OK, where a tornado tore through town killing 24 people. And, a sculptor recreates Rome’s Trevi Fountain…in cardboard.

item.title: Maxed Out On Everest (5.30.2013)
item.description: Hundreds of people are now attempting to climb Mt. Everest every year. National Geographic's Mark Jenkins says the mountain, once tackled only by professional climbers, has become accessible to anyone who can afford to pay to go up and down.  And as a result, the mountain is being ruined by garbage, human excrement, and even bodies of deceased climbers. Also in this show, we learn about a new kind of aircraft, the “Aeroscraft."  It’s a space-age looking machine that’s almost as big as a football field and able to carry 50 tons or more.

item.title: Journey From North Korea (5.29.2013)
item.description: On today’s show we meet a woman who fled North Korea for China, only to be abducted by human traffickers and sold into a marriage. Next, Dick talks with filmmaker Ann Shin, who tells us that it’s not uncommon for defectors to escape North Korea for China and find themselves in greater danger.  Ann Shin’s documentary, The Defector, follows women as they escape. Also in this show, a photographer documents the edges of the country – where North Korea borders South Korea and China.

item.title: An American Promise (5.28.2013)
item.description:
Over the course of 13 years, Joe Brewster and Michele Stephenson filmed their son’s progress through the elite New York City prep school called Dalton. As an African-American family in a predominantly white school, the years were challenging for everyone, as seen in the family’s documentary American Promise.

Also: Comedian Alaudin Ullah’s parents are Bengali, and were among the many East Indian and Bangladeshi immigrants who moved to New York at the turn of the 20th century. Alaudin has been exploring the lost history of his old neighborhood, often called “Bengali Harlem.”

item.title: Memorial Day At Camp Buehring, Kuwait (5.27.2013)
item.description:
We hear two dispatches from US Military base Camp Buehring. Chaplain Matt Stewart describes a wall of photographs of fallen soldiers, and tank mechanic Sgt. Roberto Abelardo, who witnessed the Twin Towers falling on 9-11 and decided to enlist.

Also: William B.J. Ganem knows what it’s like to lose a limb. For him, it happened in Iraq. He’s currently working to support victims of the Boston bombing in their recoveries through the Semper Fi Fund. And: Dick talks to Anna Diebold about her father’s memoirs of rescuing downed pilots in Burma during World War II.

item.title: The Pizza Purist And The Cutgirl (5.24.2013)
item.description: When other kids were out riding bikes, Anthony Mangieri was in his grandmother’s kitchen experimenting with ancient dough leavening methods. Now he makes some of the best pizzas in the country. Also in this show: A trip to the Capitol Pool Checkers Club where men with nicknames like the Hammer, the Pressure Man, and the Razor gather to play checkers; and how one woman stopped being a ring girl, and started treating the wounds of boxers.

item.title: The Free Help Guy Wants To Make Your Life Better (5.23.2013)
item.description: In his six-month project to offer help to anyone, the Free Help Guy has been asked to give a tour of London, to allow a hypnotist to hypnotize him – and a few favors he’s had to decline. Also in this show: listeners respond to the story of Adam Davis, an adjunct professor who says he’d make more money working at Starbucks; and Tio Hardiman, director of Ceasefire Illinois, says violence is down in the past weeks and he credits intensive one-on-one mediation.

item.title: Witnessing The Moore Tornado From Air And Ground (5.22.2013)
item.description: A photographer, a helicopter pilot, and an emergency room manager talk about their lives since the devastating tornado in Moore. Also in this show: Host Dick Gordon speaks with Ahmed Errachidi, a Moroccan chef who was held in Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, for five-and-a-half years under suspicion that he had ties with al-Qaeda; A former inmate at the U.S. Disciplinary Barracks at Ft. Leavenworth, Kan., on being held at a facility run by the same guards who work at the Guantanamo Bay detention camp; how the world’s biggest diamond robber’s escape was undone by a half-eaten salami sandwich.

item.title: 53 Days Without Food: Prisoners On Hunger Strike As A Last Resort (5.21.2013)
item.description: Tommy McKearney, a former prisoner and IRA fighter, tells host Dick Gordon about the Irish Republican Army hunger strikes in Northern Ireland in the 1980s – and his own 53 days without food. Also in this show: When Japanese Americans were freed from World War II internment camps, the government surplus foods they’d been fed found their way into their kitchens; and the story of a popular Asian fusion restaurant that started off in a backyard.

item.title: The Man Who Quantifies Every Moment Of Every Day (5.20.2013)
item.description: Chris Dancy is wired up to measure himself every moment of every work day, and says keeping metrics on himself has made him a better employee and will be a tool for the future of the workplace. Also in this show: Roman Mars of the 99% Invisible podcast looks back to a time when we sent information using pneumatic  tubes - the kind you might still see in a drive through bank; and host Dick Gordon checks in with Ben Harris and Scott Haren, who suffer from ALS and have tried to make their own medicine to stop the progress of their disease.

item.title: Piecing Together The Delage Coupe (5.17.2013)
item.description: Host Dick Gordon speaks with David Cooper, the part-sleuth, part-mechanic who restored a rare 1937 Delage Aerosport Coupe. Also in this show: Alex McLean, the photographer-pilot who documented New York City’s hidden skyline gardens.

item.title: How To Win A Green Card: Abdi’s Story Continues (5.16.2013)
item.description: The Story has followed the life of a school teacher from Somalia since 2009. Earlier this month, he found out that he won a visa lottery to the U.S. Also in this show: Philanthropist Melinda Gates has had conversations with mothers across the globe, and says women everywhere want to find the best care for their children. For years, dozens of runners dropped their gear at Boston’s Crossroads Irish Bar, took the subway out of town, and ran the Boston Marathon route back to the bar. And Bob Stewart, who owned Carousel Arcade in Seaside Heights, N.J., says the town is as ready as it can be for the summer season.

item.title: Editing An Encyclopedia That Changes By The Minute (5.15.2013)
item.description: Host Dick Gordon speaks with Sue Gardner, director of the Wikimedia Foundation, about how she got to her job, and how the organization is working to bring more female editors to the site. Also in this show: Actor Scott Shepherd on reading  every single word of the Great Gatsby on stage.

item.title: Towing Away The Costa Concordia Cruise Ship (5.14.2013)
item.description: Todd Busch, who is overseeing the removal of the Costa Concordia cruise ship, explains to host Dick Gordon how the vessel is expected to be towed away by December this year. Also in this show: Benji Smith and Emily Lau were celebrating their honeymoon aboard the Costa Concordia cruise ship when it started sinking; and illustrator Matt Kish tells host Dick Gordon why he made a work of art for each page of the classic Moby-Dick.

item.title: Political Season = Gun Buying Season (5.13.2013)
item.description: Larry Hyatt runs one of the biggest gun shops in the country, and he tells host Dick Gordon that as some politicians have tried to tighten gun legislation, he’s seen a growing demand for “high capacity” guns. Also in this show: William Vizzard, who tracked down firearms for almost three decades, talks about laws that helped his work; Jay Wachtel, a veteran firearms trafficking investigator, talks about the man power needed to bust a gun ring; Malcolm Shabazz, who was killed last week in Mexico, spoke to Dick in 2011 about his grandfather Malcolm X.

item.title: One String Is All You Need (5.10.2013)
item.description: Andrew Chin, a.k.a. Brushy One-String, has crafted a unique style playing a one-string guitar and singing in an utterly original voice. Also in this show: The teenage diary of Melissa, who didn’t mean to get pregnant, but when she did, she tried to build the family she herself never had.

item.title: Invisible Girls (5.9.2013)
item.description: Contributor Scott Carrier lived in the Salt Lake City neighborhood where 14-year-old Elizabeth Smart was abducted and held, and he says that we can be blind to what is right in front of us. Also in this show: Dr. T. Berry Brazelton, who is 95 and one of the country’s most respected pediatricians; and the original Teenage Diary from Josh Cutler, whose struggled with Tourette's Syndrome.

item.title: Her Majesty's Philosophers (5.8.2013)
item.description: Alan Smith taught philosophy and literature to violent criminals in prison until he realized he was “becoming more of the prison than I wanted to be.” Also in this show: the original Teenage Diary of Frankie Lewchuck, who was really close to his dad – until the day his dad almost went away for good.

item.title: Cracks In The Building (5.7.2013)
item.description: Charles Kernaghan, a labor rights activist, has pushed for governments to prioritize the rights of workers in Bangladesh and elsewhere. He talks with host Dick Gordon about the recent tragedy there. Also in this show: Adam Davis, who taught eight science classes at three colleges in Pittsburgh, has met with the United Steelworkers to talk about unionizing; and the Teenage Diary of Juan, who crossed the Rio Grande into the U.S. with his family.

item.title: No Papers and Unafraid: Daniela Pelaez Lobbies Washington (5.6.2013)
item.description: Host Dick Gordon speaks with Daniela Pelaez, a freshman at Dartmouth College who is undocumented and has been lobbying the U.S. Senate’s "Gang of Eight" for immigration reform. Also in this show: trumpet player Arturo Sandoval talks about the enormous range of his instrument; and the Teenage Diary of Amanda Brand, who had figured out she was gay, although her family insisted she was just going through a phase.

item.title: Calling Syria: Aleppo and Damascus (5.3.2013)
item.description: Host Dick Gordon checks in with Issa Touma, a resident of the Syrian city of Aleppo and occasional guest of the program. Also in this show: A Syrian living in the U.S. calls a friend who left Damascus and one who remains; and a story about the day blues guitarist Robert Johnson and cellist Pablo Casals recorded music.

item.title: 'We Are Human. Talk To Us' (5.2.2013)
item.description: Host Dick Gordon speaks with Carlos Warner, an attorney for 11 detainees held in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba. As many as 130 have been on hunger strike there since February. Also in this show: an essay from Samir Nahi al Hasan Moqbel, a detainee on hunger strike in Guantánamo Bay; George Bien, a Hungarian who was sent to a Soviet prison camp in Siberia; and Ivette Cepeda, a celebrated Cuban singer who is bringing her music to the U.S.

item.title: Crowd Sourcing Cold Cases (5.1.2013)
item.description: Host Dick Gordon speaks with Michele McNamara, author of the True Crime Diary blog. She and a community of online sleuths have helped detectives take a new look at the Golden State Killer, and other cold cases. Also in this show: contributor Roman Mars considers how architects allow and encourage space; and the man traveling the world to record the language of Jesus.

item.title: Locked Up In A Modern-Day Debtors’ Prison (4.30.2013)
item.description: Jack Dawley has been jailed three times in Ohio for failure to pay outstanding debts, and along with the American Civil Liberties Union has filed a complaint for what he says is an outdated – and unconstitutional – practice. Also in this show: Christopher Cassucio, whose “Strike Debt” group is aiming to erase people’s debts, answers listener response; and Anna & Elizabeth, the guitar-and-banjo duo that makes movies called "crankies".< /p>

item.title: A Soldier's Eye: Rediscovered Photos From Vietnam (4.29.2013)
item.description:
Charlie Haughey shot almost 2000 photographs of his fellow soldiers in Vietnam, but left the photo negatives untouched in a box for 45 years. Recently, a friend encouraged him to digitize the images and Charlie says he didn't sleep for days after revisiting the faces from his past.

Plus, at 91 years old, Henry Stone is still at work as a record producer. He remembers producing one of Ray Charles' earliest recordings, and hand-selling early R& amp;B albums in barbershops.

item.title: The Real-Life Analysts Who Led The ‘Manhunt’ For bin Laden (4.26.2013)
item.description: The untold story of the “sisterhood” of CIA analysts that led the two-decade investigation and search for Osama bin Laden. "Manhunt" premieres on HBO next week. Also in this show: GQ's Michael Hainey on his obsession with his father's secret life and mysterious death.

item.title: The Tigris, The Euphrates And The Dictator (4.25.2013)
item.description: Host Dick Gordon speaks with Azzam Alwash, an exiled Iraqi who returned to his country to restore the marshes between the Tigris and the Euphrates that Saddam Hussein had drained. Also in this show: Gabriel Kahane wand the Orpheus Chamber Orchestra are at Carnegie Hall on Saturday with a new work based on the 1930s WPA American Guide Series; and the story of passenger pigeons, which flourished in America over 100 years ago and were systematically extinguished.

item.title: For Chechen Refugee, Bombings Open Wounds Of War (4.24.2013)
item.description: Host Dick Gordon speaks with Magomed Imakaev, a Chechen refugee living near Boston who’s grappling with the bombings allegedly perpetrated by two brothers who share his roots. Also in this show: Casey McKinlay, who pulled off a 21-hour dive through underwater caves that connect sinkholes near Tallahassee, Fla.

item.title: West, Texas, Is Home (4.23.2013)
item.description: Host Dick Gordon speaks to Nita Gerik, the widow of the chief of the West, Texas, Volunteer Fire Department, and her son Jim Gerik, who is overseeing donations from the community. Then, Dick speaks with a piper and firefighter who will perform at a service for first responders killed in the West explosions. Also: Dotan Negrin, who’s traveling and playing his upright piano in New York City, New Orleans, San Antonio, and all the way to Panama.

item.title: News In 140 Characters (4.22.2013)
item.description: Guest host Sean Cole sits down with Brooke Gladstone, host of NPR's On The Media, to figure out what was true and not true on social media after the Boston Marathon bombings. Also in this show: Nick Flynn, a poet and writer who grew up in and around Boston, reads a poem about the Boston Marathon; and host Dick Gordon speaks with Benoit Rolland about making bows for violin, viola and cello.

item.title: A Man And His Piano (4.18.2013)
item.description:
Dick tracks down Dotan Negrin, who’s traveling and playing his upright piano in New York City, New Orleans, San Antonio, and all the way through Central America to Panama.

Also in this show: The story of a trio of sisters who created a small trick to make their mother think they could communicate with spirits; and a 21-hour dive through the underwater caves that connect sinkholes beneath the ground in Florida.

item.title: Finding A Way Out Of North Korea (4.18.2013)
item.description:
Sokeel Park of the U.S.-based NGO Liberty in North Korea talks to host Dick Gordon about how young North Koreans use illegal cell phones to get outside information and how security has been tightened in the country.

Also in this show: The story of two teenagers in a small North Korean town from Barbara Demick’s book Nothing to Envy: Ordinary Lives in North Korea; and the story of the Kowloon Walled City in Hong Kong and how it grew in an organic way.

item.title: Combing The Debris - After The Bombing (4.17.2013)
item.description:
Malcolm Brady, former assistant director of the ATF, tells host Dick Gordon about the 1993 World Trade Center bombing, and how they dug into the rubble to get the frame of the van that carried the explosives - and identify who rented it.

Also in this show: Scotland Yard Detective Chief InspectorArnie Cook worked in anti-terrorism for more than 30 years during a series of bombings in London; and map maker Dave Imus set out to create a better map of the U.S. - one that delineates the states and rivers and forests with more clarity.

item.title: Bombings At The Boston Marathon (4.16.2013)
item.description:
Dick Gordon speaks with longtime Boston Marathon announcer and runner Kathrine Switzer, who was covering the event on Monday and witnessed the explosions.

Also in this show: When Kimberly Wasserman learned that health problems and death were tied to the smokestacks in her Chicago neighborhood, she got them shut down and was awarded a Goldman Environmental Award for her work; and writer Christopher Hanson is campaigning to get journalist Edward Kennedy recognition for reporting on the end of World War II.

item.title: Strike Debt (4.15.13)
item.description: A group of activists is purchasing student debt from collectors and simply "forgiving it." Also: New York City has agreed to reimburse the Occupy Wall Street Library fordestroyed books. And: a font that is more readable for those with dyslexia.

item.title: Puppeteer Basil Twist And The Rite Of Spring (4.12.13)
item.description: The Rite of Spring by Igor Stravinsky almost caused a riot when it was first seen 100 years ago. Today it has become a classic and is being celebrated on its centenary- yet eyebrows can still be raised when a puppeteer stages his version. That production premieres today. Also: Wildlife photographer Tim Laman tells Dick about his journey to photograph every species of the Birds of Paradise.

item.title: On The Bus With Candidate Margaret Thatcher (4.11.2013)
item.description: Dick speaks with retired BBC broadcaster Robin Lustig about his many years of listening and watching former Prime Minister Thatcher. Also: Roman Mars on design, Soviet-style. And: Dick speaks with Jim Scott about his battle with the CIA to find out why they agency wiretapped his father.

item.title: Journey To The Centroid Of The Country (4.10.2013)
item.description: Orion Magazine writer Jeremy Miller explores the exact center of the U.S. population, and finds that its movement has paralleled the country's westward expansion and development. Also in this show: An audio meditation on riding the bus to work every day; and artist Bo Gehring makes portraits with a slow moving camera set to music.

item.title: Calling Home To Baghdad (4.9.2013)
item.description: Ten years after the U.S. invasion of Iraq, host Dick Gordon and interpreter Ahmed Fadaam recall covering the capital city. Also in this show: Khalid Ansari, who still thinks of the deaths he witnessed during the war; and Mohammed Hafudh, a civil servant in the oil industry who plans to run for office to try and reform the government.

item.title: Mom's Death And The End Of Life Talk (4.5.2013)
item.description: Charlie Ornstein, a journalist covering health-care, was the go-to guy in his family on all questions medical. But when he found his mother was on life support, he found he had few answers. Also in this show: We hear from listeners about our interview with healthcare advocate Pat Palmer who analyzes bills from hospitals. And Mexican painter Frida Kahlo’s clothes were locked up for 50 years. We speak with the woman who created an exhibit with them.

item.title: Game Of Change (4.5.2013)
item.description: In 1963, Jerry Harkness was the African American captain of the Loyola Chicago Ramblers.  He tells Dick about the moment he realized he was part of history. Also in this show: Brian Banks, who spent more than five years in jail on a false rape accusation, has just signed with the Atlanta Falcons; and the Grammy-winning, Nashville banjo picker Jim Mills in his own words.

item.title: Stop And Frisk On Trial In New York City (4.4.2013)
item.description: We hear from Nicholas Peart, who has been stopped by the New York City Police Department three times, and is one of the young men behind a lawsuit against the department’s “Stop and Frisk” policy. Also in this show: Radio Rookies reporters Ephraim Fromer and Temitayo Fagbenle interview Police Commissioner Raymond Kelly. And David Keller talks about teaching philosophy and values to students who are Mormon.

item.title: A Veteran's Wife Is Diagnosed With PTSD - From Reliving The War With Him (4.3.2013)
item.description: Since Kat Honaker’s husband returned from serving in Iraq, she has been reliving the war with him, and has been diagnosed with PTSD. Also in this show: U.S. Army psychiatrist Dr. Stephen Xenakis talks about new approaches to cope with Traumatic Brain Injury, or TBI.

item.title: Creating Art To Survive (4.2.2013)
item.description: Zofia Abramowicz, a Polish Catholic, was taken to Auschwitz during World War II, wrote poetry, and buried it in the camp. Sean Cole talks to the keeper of these poems, Cherie Braun. Also in this show: Sean talks with Thomas Schultz, who found thousands of paintings in a garage when he was looking at houses on Long Island. The paintings were by Arthur Pinajian and are now worth $30 million.

item.title: The $400 Tylenol Pill, And How To Get A Better Price (4.1.2013)
item.description: Pat Palmer, who has worked in a hospital billing office, shares her tricks for finding savings in the fine print of a medical bill. Also in this show: John Fischer turned to researchers and philosophers as they attempt to answer the question, "What happens next?"

item.title: "Pee Wee" Kirkland and Harlem's Rucker Park (3.29.13)
item.description: Jumping at the Sky: the stories of Harlem's street ball great "Pee Wee" Kirkland, and the choir that is no longer silent.

item.title: Shadow Lives (3.28.13)
item.description: Guest host Sean Cole explores the lives of Islamic women and men who have been rounded up, sent to prison or put under surveillance. Victoria Brittain has spent years meeting and interviewing the families of suspects imprisoned in London and Guantanamo Bay, Cuba and that is the basis for her book Shadow Lives: The Forgotten Women of the War on Terror.

item.title: A Family Unmade And Made Again
item.description: Producers Alex Kotlowitz and Amy Drozdowska capture the unfolding connection between a man and his adopted adopted son. Also in this show: the story of a beep baseball player.

item.title: 98 Minutes (3.26.13)
item.description: WBEZ and the Center for Public Integrity investigate the case of a man who’s burned by water and chemicals at work.

item.title: Seven Things You Should Never Say to a Vet (3.25.13)
item.description: Jason Moon, an Iraq War vet, talks to guest host Sean Cole about the seven things people say to veterans that alienate and anger them.

item.title: Saving Groucho (3.22.13)
item.description: Guest host Sean Cole speaks to Andy Marx about the phone call his grandfather Groucho Marx got from a man offering him the archives of his hit show "You Bet Your Life."

item.title: Telling The Untellable (3.22.13)
item.description: Alicia Partnoy, who was held in a secret prison in Argentina, speaks to Sean Cole about the place called the Little School. The naming of the Buenos Aires cardinal as pope has brought up memories of the country’s Dirty War, during which thousands of citizens were kidnapped and killed.

item.title: Penpals With The Unabomber (3.20.13)
item.description: A professor exhanges hundreds of letters with "The Unabomber" about the perils of technology, and an audio tour of vintage transcription disks from WWII.

item.title: Spiritual Warfare: Evangelical Protestants Convert Catholics (3.19.13)
item.description: Spirituality becomes entangled with politics in Guatemala, plus Luc Sante on the "novels" of Félix Fénéon and a reading from poet Charles Bernstein.

item.title: March 18, 2013 Show
item.description: As the Senate begins to consider a ban on assault weapons, we offer a collection of stories about Americans and guns.< /p>

item.title: March 15, 2013 Show
item.description: Writer Alexandra Fuller told her husband she wanted to leave. Minutes later, he had a terrible accident and the end of her relationship became entwined with the accident. Also in this show: Producer Phoebe Judge talks to Claudine Andre of the Democratic Republic of Congo, who helped establish a sanctuary for bonobos.

item.title: March 14, 2013 Show
item.description: Western writer Terry Tempest Williams spent 25 years sorting out the message her mother gave her when she left her three shelves of blank journals.

item.title: March 13, 2013 Show
item.description: Cardinal Cormac Murphy-O'Connor, who was inside the Vatican in 2005, describes the process of deciding who would become the new pope. Also in this show: a gay Catholic priest presses from the inside for change; and Basque sheepherders reveal cooking traditions from their work out west.

item.title: March 12, 2013 Show
item.description: Dick speaks with Travis Williams about the heavy caseload he carries in Hall Country, Ga., and to Al Flora, the chief public defender of Luzerne County, Pa., about having to decline new cases. Also in this show: A young man in a youth residential facility calls home to speak with his family.

item.title: March 11, 2013 Show
item.description: Dick calls Japanese farmer Mitsuo Sato, who lived close to the Fukushima Daiichi reactor before the tsunami in 2011. He is part of a crew that is decontaminating the soil in his farming community. Also in this show: Japanese photographer Shimpei Tekada collected contaminated soil and placed it on film; and photographer Wendy Ewald re-visits an Innu community after 40 years.

item.title: March 08, 2013 Show
item.description: Rafael Simón Jiménez was a high school friend of Venezuela President Hugo Chavez, who died this week. As the country mourns, Dick speaks with Rafael Simón about the leader as a young man. Also in this show: A dreamy trip to Brazil, Argentina and France through the music of Dom la Nena.

item.title: March 07, 2013 Show
item.description: Betsy Andreu is married to a cycling teammate of Lance Armstrong. She spoke out on his taking banned drugs, and was reviled for her statements. Also in this show: Dick speaks with 23-year-old Mayor Alex Morse, who has been running Holyoke, Mass., for a year.

item.title: March 06, 2013 Show
item.description: A conversation with Terence White, the longest serving foreign correspondent in Afghanistan. Also in this show: We hear from soldiers in Afghanistan about the equipment and personal items they carry.

item.title: March 05, 2013 Show
item.description: Ken Dufalla watches for fish kills and chemicals in the water from coal and fracking sites in Green County, Pa. Also in this show: Author Carter Sickels reads from “The Evening Hour,” and Jim Hays commissioned a novel about the succession of Texas to make a point about the federal government.

item.title: March 04, 2013 Show
item.description: Dick speaks with Mike Hankey about how he got his start hunting down meteor fragments in rural Amish farmland. Also in this show: Dick speaks with Olympic wrestler Clarissa Chun who is joining forces to lobby the International Olympic Committee to keep wrestling in Olympic competition; and writer John Irving, a life-long wrestler, speaks from his exercise room.

item.title: March 01, 2013 Show
item.description: Known as a vocalist for the 1970's rock band Roxy Music, Bryan Ferry strips some of his classics of vocals and reinvents them in the style of 1920's jazz. Tune in to hear Avalon with trumpet, banjo and bass sax. Also in this show: 99% Invisible explores a Philadelphia park that became a mecca for skaters.

item.title: February 28, 2013 Show
item.description: Building a car, a battery powered car that can go up to 400 miles per hour. It's under way at Ohio State University. Also in this show: We call David Cundall in Burma to check in on his attempt to dig up old World War II era planes – Spitfires; a story about a slave who hides in a wooden box and sends himself to freedom; and a poem from Martin Espada.

item.title: February 27, 2013 Show
item.description: When Peter Hessler first arrived in the remote Chinese river town of Fuling, the only way to get there was by boat. Recently, he went back for a visit to explore the changes that the Three Gorges Dam has made. Also in this show: Dick speaks with Denise Dennis, who is in a charge of her family farm - one that reaches back to before Abraham Lincoln was born.

item.title: February 26, 2013 Show
item.description: Today we have three gun stories about how and why people own a firearm. Also in this show: Dick and producer Phoebe Judge read letters about gun owner Yang Li and his passionate defense of gun ownership.

item.title: February 25, 2013 Show
item.description: Dick speaks with Richard Wright, who has negotiated the release of kidnap victims in Mexico and other countries. Also in this show: Photographer Katie Orlinsky was based in Mexico and she saw that women were caught up in the drug wars and began to document it; and a soundscape of the Sonoran desert between Arizona and Mexico.< /p>

item.title: February 22, 2013 Show
item.description: Mark Lijek was working in the American embassy in Iran when it was taken over by militant students. He tells the real-life story behind the film Argo. Also in this show: Filmmaker Wim Wenders tells Claes Andreaasson that having a story board from start to finish is boring, and he likes to make things up as he goes; and Fereshta Kazemi left Hollywood to act in her childhood country - Afghanistan.

item.title: February 21, 2013 Show
item.description: Growing up with Anne Frank – a childhood friend remembers a vibrant, curious girl. Also in this show: Robert MacFarlane reads from his latest, "The Old Ways: A Journey On Foot."

item.title: February 20, 2013 Show
item.description: Charles Hill has a list of paintings he loves - some have been stolen, some he has recovered. Also: Dick speaks with documentary filmmaker Kate Schermerhorn about After Happily Ever After.

item.title: February 19, 2013 Show
item.description: Dick speaks with Yang Li, who was born and raised in China. As soon as he got his citizenship in the U.S., he bought a gun.

item.title: February 18, 2013 Show
item.description: Host Dick Gordon spends a day in Sandy Seaside Heights, N.J., where some peole are rebuilding, and others are chosing not to. Also in this show: the group of fishermen who started their own business to sell directly to consumers; and listener reaction to the story of Brian Banks, who spent five years in prison on a wrongful rape accusation.

item.title: February 18, 2013 Show
item.description: Hassina Sherjan, a frequent guest from Afghanistan, tells Dick that Kabul has gotten safer, and that she often goes out at night for poetry recitals. Also in this show: an Afghan photographer who returned 22 years after he left as a refugee; two women who greet returning U.S. soldiers at the Dallas/ Fort Worth airport; poet Naomi Shihab Nye on maamoul cookies; and a 24-hour music festival.

item.title: February 15, 2013 Show
item.description: Dick speaks with Justin Torres, author of We The Animals, about his inspiration: Dorothy Allison. He then speaks with Dorothy Allison about her inspiration: Toni Morrison. Also in this show: Artist Toni Scott’s life-size castings of slaves.< /span>

item.title: February 14, 2013 Show
item.description: Dick speaks with Toby and Itzhak Perlman about their marriage of 46 years, and how they met at music camp and became friends listening to classical music on records.

item.title: February 13, 2013 Show
item.description: British Parliament member Jack Straw tells the story of a killing spree in Scotland in 1997 and how it spurred a gun ban.

item.title: February 12, 2013 Show
item.description: South African Thembi Simelane has been seeking the truth of the disappearance of her sister, who was interrogated and tortured during apartheid

item.title: February 11, 2013 Show
item.description: Guest host Sean Cole goes to see his mother about a family rifle left to him by his grandfather.
